1.words: Okay. All right. So I just have to read this beginning piece and then we'll get into the questions. Welcome to this conversation sponsored by Education Action Forum of Maine, and Educate Maine on Cortico's Local Voices Network. There are three main purposes for this conversation. First, we want to create a new way for community members to listen and learn about each other's experiences, values, and perspectives, especially around education. Second, we want to gather voices from all around the state to inform the direction of Maine's educational system. And third, we want to create a unique listening channel through which we lift up the voices and needs of a whole state, every county, in order to build a healthier public sphere, and education is a part of that. So we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing our personal stories from our lived experiences, rather than beginning the conversation with our position on issues. Following our conversation today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of the LVN collection. The data is owned by the Education Action Forum of Maine, and you will receive an email following the conversation, giving you access to it as well. What you say will be publicly available but only publicly identifiable by how you introduce yourself. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Education Action Forum of Maine, and Educate Maine to use the recording in accordance with the mission of Maine ED-250. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand, and agree to this, please say "I agree." So we have your [inaudible] consent to use it.

8.words: All right. First we have some conversation agreements. We ask that you feel free to pick up on threads from what you have heard others say here. Share fully and leave time for everyone to participate. Listen openly and ask questions when you want to know more about something that you have heard. Remember that it is not a debate or about winning, or even about finding an agreement, it's just about sharing experiences and ideas and listening to others. We are going to use the circle process, so we're just going to go around this way so that everyone has a chance to speak. And you can always say pass or ask for us to come back to you. To begin, let's do a quick round of introductions, just a sentence or two. So please share your first name, the county and town you live in, and a specific example of a time you felt you mattered to your community. Start right with this side.

9.words: My name's Edge. I live in Robbinston, which is in Washington County, and I felt like I mattered to my community when they asked me to go on a work trip to a Cadcom forum in Washington DC, and presented about a camp that we did back home and spread the news about it in the area to the whole country.

10.words: My name's Rowan. I live in Machias, Washington County, and I feel like what I do matters to the community when I'm asked to present a workshop and after the workshop, people of any age come up to me and tell me that they really got something out of it.

11.words: I'm Linden from Lubec, Washington County. And there's this one time in eighth grade that I was asked to sit on my town's recycling committee as a student representative, and that meant a lot to me.

12.words: My name's Acadia. I'm from Whitefield. That's in Lincoln County. And I was a part of a Color Run for Cancer, a cancer walk, and it felt really good that all these people were coming up to me and supporting it.

13.words: Hi. I'm Nick. I live in the Machiasport, which is in Washington County. I felt important when my course that I'm in, Washington County Children's Course, I was asked to come back to France another time and perform at the two-day class next fall.

14.words: Hi, I'm Lauralie. I am from Washington County and I felt important when I was asked to come back to the training dinners to help out and volunteer.

15.words: Nice. Okay, now we're going to get started with the question. So first one's just a basic one. What does it mean to you to have a good life? And do you think adults around you see it differently?

16.words: For me, to have a good life, you should be able to have your freedoms to do what you please in a way that is safe for everyone and yourself around you and you are having fun and you feel happy and you have rights to live as you are and the adults in my life, I think have very similar views. They all strive to keep me happy and give me the best life that they can give, to the best of their ability.

17.words: Okay, the question was, what does it mean to have a good life? And do you think the adults around you see it differently?

18.words: For me having a good life means being around good people, people I can just connect with and people that are open to connect with me. That's what being a good person means to me, the openness and honesty that communication is approached with. So I think adults around me oftentimes share that value, but it might not be exactly what they think of when they think of having a good life.

20.words: What does it mean to you to have a good life? And do you think that adults around you see it differently?

21.words: What it means to me to have a good life is just for me to be happy, no matter where I am and also just be financially stable. I think the adults around me, they do share the same sentiment with the financially stable part. But, that happiness part, I don't think so much. They're just kind of financially stable, that's it.

22.words: I feel like for me it is financially stable, happy, but I don't think my people, grownups around me really understand what it is to be happy.

23.words: Yeah, living a good life is a life where you enjoy yourself, where you're able to do things that give you joy and feeling comfortable doing all those things in the community. I interact with a lot of different adults on a day-to-day basis, in my usual life. And I would say that the majority of those adults I interact with would definitely agree that being able to do the things that you enjoy and being comfortable doing that is important to enjoying your life. More often, times when you get older, people are more worried about physical things, such as money and possessions.

24.words: I agree with pretty much everything that's been said so far. And I think that the big part of enjoying your life is being able to make your own choices without worrying about finances or any other thing. And I think that that's something that most people understand and it might just be personalized a little bit more for people.

25.words: Awesome. Can you share a mental picture of where you'll be in 10 years and will you be living in the same town? Where in Maine? Why or why not?

26.words: I think there's a possibility that I might be in Maine. I don't know if I'm going to be in the same town, because I might want to move out and get my own house. But I do really like Maine because I like the environment and everything and I'm going to be hopefully doing more work that's focused on helping the environment and wherever that is, I don't know, but that's what I want to be doing.

27.words: Can you share a picture of where you will be in 10 years? Will you be living in the same town in Maine and why?

28.words: I love being in Maine. I'm not sure if I'll still be here in 10 years. I want to leave to study things for a while, but I love Maine a lot for environmental reasons and also for privacy reasons. I love that you can live here and not a lot of people will ask you questions. You can keep to yourself and engage when you want to and at both of those times, you're met with the same kind of feelings, you can reach out or you can stay put. And I really love that. So I really do love being in this area of Maine. I would love to stay on the coast. So hopefully, in 10 years I'll either be here happy or be somewhere else on the coast and be happy and probably planning to return at some point.

29.words: I don't think we can give a very good description of where I'm going to be in 10 years. I probably won't be in Maine I do have to say. I just feel like there are just bigger things outside of Maine that I haven't found yet. And that feeling has been nagging at me my entire life. So I've got to get out of here, but I do plan on coming back to Maine to retire as an old man.

30.words: Yeah, I like Maine, I don't love Maine. I don't like how much of my life I've missed because I've lived here, which is weird to say, but I want adventure. But I also don't want to pay millions of dollars to go out and find my adventure. In 10 years I plan on still being in med school, racking up that debt. So probably not in 10 years, getting out of Maine, but I'm hoping to.

31.words: Where I see myself in 10 years? I couldn't honestly tell you. I've only experienced a gap of 10 years, roughly one time, considering the fact that I'm 19-years-old. So that's a long look in the future. Wherever I am, be it here or moving elsewhere, I hope I'm comfortable. Whether or not I'm in Maine, I'm not sure. I moved here when I was seven or so from another country and I have been thinking about my family over there more and more recently and the problems that come with living in America especially, less so Maine. We're not very populous here and I do miss interacting with people on the everyday scale outside of work. Recently I've been thinking about what I want to do for a job and I'm not sure. So both those questions are a little bit up in the air.

32.words: I can't say definitely where I want to be in 10 years, but I know that I want to have traveled by the 10 year mark now. And besides that, I'm not sure. So everything's a little up in the air, like you said before, and crazy.

33.words: How do you want to contribute to your community in the future and how does work or career fit into that?

34.words: To me, my community is the whole earth. So I want to be able to help people and preserve the place so that everyone has a space to live where they're safe and they have resources. So hopefully my work will allow me to do that and I'll find a job that keeps me stable and I'm able to keep other people stable.

35.words: People for me is really what life is all about. I love working with people and I love working for people. And I love working for the benefit of people. One thing I'm really passionate about is health education. I think that could take huge strides forward and I want to work in a field where maybe I can push some of that information forward.

36.words: I want to give back to people who have helped me and in a way, most of them are gone but I want to go into the medical field and I want to be in the US Air Force so I can be helping my community and the world every day and fighting for what I believe is right.

37.words: Can I catch that question one more time?

38.words: Yeah, how do you want to contribute to your community and how does work for your career fit into that, if it does?

39.words: I've always wanted the people around me to be happier. I suppose community is just a broader extent of that. Like I mentioned in a previous question, I'm not exactly sure what I want to go into, what I want to do, how I want to make my livelihood. Whatever it is, I would like to give back, especially in this community, there are a lot of problems with social mobility and stagnation. So if I do wind up staying around here, I'd love to create opportunities for the people around me. Not exactly sure how I would do that necessarily, to get there.

40.words: I'm also not sure what I want to do exactly, but I do know whatever I want, whatever I choose, will be something to help the people in my community because that's just always been something that I've really valued.

41.words: Yeah. How does voting or being civically engaged matter to you?

42.words: To me, the perfect system of voting is that every person has a say in what they do. So one man, one vote is one way to do it. And I think it's important that in a country that everyone gets a say in how or what's going to happen. And it's important to me because if you don't have that freedom and someone else is telling you what to do all the time, then how is that right? Because they might be doing something that is so wrong to yourself and to others and you can't do anything to stop it. So voting and using your voice is important to speak up and make change when possible.

43.words: Voting is really important to me because I care really strongly that other people understand that it is just such an important freedom to exercise.

44.words: Yeah, it sucks when a small group of people decide for the masses. I think it's... Just let people decide for themselves. And I know a lot of people feel a little hopeless when they vote they're like, "Oh, there's a favorite," but there have been elections in the past that have come down to just a handful votes, I would say.

45.words: Yeah, I agree. Voting is your voice in the matter but there's so little we can do out there and that's just one more thing that we actually have the right to so...

46.words: Voting. In this technological age that we are now living in, I think the only way to orchestrate voting is in a direct democracy and the more community oriented we can make this, the better. We should be deciding as a people what happens for the people who we interact with. We should not be subject to the choices of a select few, hundreds and hundreds of miles away from us. I'm sure there's more to add, but I've gone blank.

47.words: To me, voting is how you decide how to help your community around you because you're the only one who would know how to help your community, as opposed to people, like you said, that are miles and miles away. They're not going to know what your community needs and how to help it without actually having been there and experienced it so that's just how you would help your community.

48.words: Yeah, and if anyone has anything to ever add-on, just feel free to speak up, but what experiences, skills or capacities do you think you'll need to thrive and succeed in your future?

49.words: I think I have a pretty good list of experiences I've had so far, but I do want more. I want to go see more places to see what it's like for people. I want to go meet more people from all over the world and make more connections. And I want to keep being a leader in organizing and getting people together to help make a change for whatever is needed in whatever situation I'm in. And just more of what I've been doing now, like meeting people, practicing being a leader and being an organizer.

51.words: Yeah. What experiences, skills or capacities do you think you'll need to thrive and succeed in your future?

52.words: I think communication is a really important skill that I already super appreciate, but I want to build more on to get farther. I think that's my biggest value probably. And I think if I keep working on how to communicate with other people and when to communicate with other people and even why to communicate with other people, then I will be getting farther in the places that I want to go.

53.words: I think I've good shoes on my feet. I would say I've got a good foundation under me but yeah, like you said, communication skills. Sometimes I lack in those. I do want to be more well-traveled, I would say. [inaudible].

54.words: I think as a skill that I really need is experience honestly. Experience with different people, different cultures and stuff like that.

55.words: Yeah, I'd say empathy is a big one that hasn't been touched on yet. The ability to empathize with another human being, to understand their problems more from their lens than your own. Not having that ability, not being able to understand why a person might be upset about something you don't understand, drives people apart. So being able to empathize and communicate clearly and effectively. What is happening, what is important to you?

56.words: Yeah, and communication has always been a really big value or skill that I have tried to improve on. And other than that, I just want to experience different cultures and see how they do things and see the different values and norms that they have too.

57.words: Awesome. What role has school played in preparing you for your future and for the future you would like to have?

58.words: School has shown me how I don't want to live my life because there has just been so much rules and overbearing structure that makes it miserable for me and so many other of my peers and I feel like it literally dims my light and makes me not want to do anything. And everything that has propelled me forward has been outside of school, has been through different programs with adults that actually listen and care about me. And I've met really good people at my schools and I've made really good friends at school, but we have just thrived much better outside of the school system in America.

59.words: I really struggled with school which has made me, at different points, care a lot more about education and be so fed up with education that I don't want to care about it at all, but I think what school has given me is the outside connections that come into school. For instance, Danny's Team Leadership Camp, I learned about that through school. I learned about a lot of other interesting workshops and got connected with a lot of other youth advisors through school. So I think that was a really big benefit from my education.

60.words: School's done jack-shit for me. I've met great people there, truly lots of peers, lots of friends, but really it hasn't done anything for me. And there's just been times where I'm like, the education system doesn't care about me individually, it just wants to get me through, give me a diploma and just keep me [inaudible] again. So it really hasn't... Nothing I can think of.

61.words: Yeah, I agree. I do not like school at all. Hasn't done anything for me, given me drama problems, problems outside of school, problems inside of school, waste of my time. But I am going for another eight years into the medical field. So eight more years in college that I know is going to suck but I think, honestly, when we were younger, we really wanted to go to school. That's what I looked forward to was going to school, seeing all my friends, painting, all of that. And then when I hit fifth grade, I did not want to go into school anymore. And I think that's part of how my school was. My school really focused on hierarchy, like cliques and stuff like that, also the food was gross. I just wish they'd be more engaging, but how do you do that when honestly the teachers are there just to make money? They're not really there for the people.

62.words: Could I catch the question one more time?

63.words: Yeah. What role does school play in preparing you for the future you would like to have?

64.words: For preparing the future you'd like to have? School, for a lot of people, does a reasonable job at getting them to high school and then from there on out, you kind of get chewed up and put through in a way that works, not really works until you stumble along until college. And maybe you really enjoy the education system. But school prepares you, you can't see the air quotes I'm doing, "prepares you" in the method that they stamp you with a cookie cutter and then all the little cookie children go through to cookie high school. It creates a lot of problems. It doesn't do everything that everyone needs. I think we need a lot of education reform to get to a more reasonable place. I don't even want to talk about the subject matter of school because there's a lot of things that are left out for classist or racist reasons. There are a lot of problems with... I'll cut it short talking about the problems. I don't think it's the worst thing that happens, but for a lot of people it is not what they need at the time they need it so...

65.words: Yeah, for me, school was not always the best thing, but it wasn't the worst. So there's definitely some problems with schools' mental health awareness, but at the same time, school is the reason that I have social skills and know how to make friends and stuff like that. So while there are some benefits to school, like it teaches you how to study and stuff like that and for college or your future life, it also needs to have some improvements made upon it.

66.words: I'll say at my school, free speech, not allowed. You get suspended for that.

67.words: 100%, I agree, but I was also going to say, I'm not in college, but my whole family is so... Colleges also, you got to pay for classes like basket weaving and stuff like that, that we don't need at all. People don't have that money.

68.words: If you're paying for basket weaving, it means you want to do basket weaving. So you're paying for something you want to do. I'd say college is probably other than the fact that it is way too expensive, is probably the best out of the education system. I'd say most of the fundamental problems, for me at least, existed at a lot of those lower levels.

69.words: And I think when you're damaged at a lower level, when you go through the primary school or high school or grade school and you're struggling there, then you're not really going to get out of that funk with your high school, you're still going to have that mistrust of the education system. And it's not going to come back for you in the way it should.

70.words: Does anyone else have anything to add? We're good? Okay. What might school or preparation for adult life look like if it perfectly fit your needs? Your ideal school system, basically.

71.words: I would like to begin with that it's free or at least accessible for everybody in a way that the professors still get compensated for their work and their time, but it does not ruin your financial situation for the next 20 years of your life. And I also think that it needs to have for an adult, whatever skills that they want or need for whatever career that they're choosing. But can I backtrack to high school?

73.words: Okay. Because in high school and lower levels, they need to teach more empathy and more basic human rights in school and just show everyone that they need to be more accepting of people and education on sexual education and just basic things that every single person goes through that they, for some reason, decide to ignore because they decided that it's stigmatized and kids don't need to learn about it, even though we do. So all the things that are needed. And then when they teach you about basic subjects like math and stuff, make it more engaging so that kids aren't going to fall asleep halfway through and not learn anything. And then you're going to get mad at them because they're failing their test, but it's not their fault.

74.words: I think financial problems are right up there or at the base of the pyramid. That's just this huge, huge problem. I think so much could be better if teachers were compensated properly. But then I look at it as a whole and it's so hard to just address the fact that the education system, it's based off of pleasing people instead of helping people at this point. But I wish it was based off helping people. Like Edge said, I wish those round, simple rules, simple teachings were taught so early. I wish there were no taboo topics. I wish there was actual sex ed. I wish there was actual help. Fast. I wish there were basic hygiene. I wish so much more was taught at a lower level without that stigma. I wish that was possible. Or if that was possible, I wish it was happening. I wish we could think of it as possible at least because I think a lot of people don't think that it's possible. And I think that's all I have to say right now, but I'll probably have more in a minute.

75.words: Just the school system in general was built for a different generation in a different time and it just doesn't work now. Back then, they could afford all the things that are just normal now. Like sure, people could afford to go to college before, do this and that and that. It was just a different time. Literally the school system is made to just birth factory workers. I'm just thinking, I would like to know how to do my taxes. I don't know how to do them. I really don't. And I'm going to have to start doing those in three or four years and I feel very unprepared. So I just feel like life skills in general should just be done.

76.words: And I also feel like school needs to adhere to the kids' needs. Like if they have a mental health issue, they're not going to be learning the same way. They're not. They're going to be spacey, like ADHD, stuff like that. They need to adhere to everyone's needs. And right now I don't believe that there's enough people or enough resources to do that. So maybe spending a little bit less time using people and a little bit more time actually helping people that actually need help.

77.words: It was what the ideal school looks like, right?

79.words: Yeah. Like some of my other group members, school would look a lot different. We have the money to make it really, really nice, but for some reason we do not prioritize the generations that are coming through, millions and millions of people per year, going through the school system. We have the money to pay teachers a fair living wage, and there's enough interest in it to do it so that we don't need shortages, so we don't have shortages or these education deserts where it's hard to get an education. When you're actually in the education system, we need to really help people understand what is important, less droning and on and on about how to... It's a tough question. The perfect school system is going to look a lot different for different people. I think there are things that we could do to fundamentally improve it. I think personally that we should spend more time educating on bias, I suppose. We have a lot of racial bias, a lot of sexual bias, a lot of identity bias just in general. We don't teach the important parts of our history, I'd say. We teach our weird whitewashed version of history that every kid gets when they go to school. It doesn't need to run your bank account into the ground when you go to get higher education and it doesn't need to be... What is it? Eight hours, nine hours a day, five days a week. That's too much. It's a tough question to tackle because there are a lot of aspects. I think it needs to be different. It's going to take a lot of people working very hard together for the betterment of people to make it more functional things.

80.words: Does anyone have anything to add?

81.words: I will say when we are reforming education systems, please include youth voices because we know [inaudible].

84.words: All right. What's one thing that you've heard today that you want adults in charge of making the rules about schools or school systems to know?

87.words: So what is something you've heard today or that you thought of that you want adults in charge of making rules about schools or school systems to know?

88.words: Well, I think Linden just said it, was include youth voices and listen to us. You have this conversation, listen to us and actually take action with it. Call more people in and we'll tell you more. We have so much to say and just listen to us and listen to other youth, not just the ones in this room, but everybody because everyone has something to say and it's all important. And for so long you've been disregarding us. You've just been putting us in this system that you think works and you don't even think about how it's affecting people and you just say, "Oh, I'm getting my job done," but you're not. You're hurting us. And you're hurting a lot of people and we want to make the change. So if you're giving us a chance to, then I think you should give us a call because I will talk to you.

90.words: I think it's really important to put on the table that teachers need to be valued more. You need to go higher up than... You need to listen to the students. Then you need to listen to the teachers because above that is the administration and that's where everything's falling apart. And I think you need to listen to everyone who's being affected by that because right now, no one is benefiting from this. Teachers are treated like crap, paid like crap, un-respected and this system is pleasing someone who isn't even involved in it. Essentially.

91.words: I would say just having gone through the school system, I know a lot of people with learning disabilities and whatnot. They have a different path, program in school, but the things they're taught sometimes aren't applicable to them and that whole system, I think, needs some more rework until we're at it.

92.words: I think teachers not being compensated for their work, in turn, falls back on the students because teachers aren't being compensated, they aren't going to feel the best, they're not going to, I don't think, do the best. And if they're not being compensated for 100%, what they deserve, they're going to be, I don't want to say depressed because that's... But they're not going to be as eager, to disappoint the classrooms and stuff like that. I also think that 100% having every school have, not a student council because a student council is so... I don't like it at all. It's useless.

94.words: It's useless. The hierarchy. I don't like it. They should have voices. You should have a person that talks a lot. Then you should have one that's shy, as long as they want to. And it needs to represent everyone in the school. It can't just be like, "Oh, you're the number one person." No, you need to represent all of the people in the school. You can't just go to the number one or the number two.

95.words: Thanks. Add in. So yeah, the student council right now is more of just who wants to get into a big, important college instead of people who actually want to represent their classmates and make a difference in their school. So we need a group of people who's actually going to want to make a difference instead of just want to use it as a stepping stool to an important school. Yeah.

96.words: I think schools should value more voices than just the voices of student council. I think not everyone has time to dedicate themselves to something that big, but that doesn't mean they don't care at all. I think everybody cares. And I think there are so many more ways that you could tap into youth voices other than just listening to student councils or groups like student council.

97.words: I will say having been like a class president, now I'm a student counselor [inaudible] but it seems like a lot of the time we're undervalued a lot, especially with the adults. And it's just hard to do really anything for our class because we are so undervalued, just seen as like a bunch of kids to do fundraising and do the baskets. It a little more than that. I will say there are some kids out there who are passionate and actually want to help out. They have gotten into it. They've actually spoken their truth.

98.words: Student council just feels like another adult controlled group. It's just another school grounded group and the adults that are running are going to tell you, this is what you're going to be passionate about. Or this is what we want you to talk about. And there's just so much freedom there that is not being used. It's so controlled.

99.words: To add onto that. It's not just student council at that point. Other free speaking, free idea groups really aren't all that. A lot of the time, somebody is in charge giving you the agenda and telling you what your focus is for this group. Even if it is supposed to be student oriented or student led, it's all under the same thumb of administration. If they don't want something to be talked about, then it won't be talked about. There is not a lot of voice for people who want to share their ideas. And then my own thought completely separate from that is, as I get back to the question, is everybody's different. I think when we're talk today about everybody having different ideas, even in this group, there's no be all, end all. Just taking the time to listen to people around you can do... Really listen and really implement afterwards can do so much.

100.words: Yeah. So those are all the questions that we have. Are there any closing thoughts that anyone would like to share before I read the ending?

101.words: I'd say fuck the school system.

102.words: Freedom of speech in the school system.

103.words: The problems up there with administration. You need to get higher. You need to get higher and listen to the lower people and change the higher up system.

104.words: Yeah, because there wouldn't be a system without us, there wouldn't be-

105.words: Listen low and change things up at the top.

106.words: Anyone else? Or are we good?

107.words: Michelle Obama said, when they go low, we go high.

111.words: All right, real quick, I just have to read this last thing and then we'll be all set. So this is just a reminder of what will happen with the thoughts you just shared. These recordings will be transcribed and uploaded to lvn.org, a web based tool for listening to an exploring conversations on lv.org. You can search conversations, listening to audio snippets and discover patterns. You will receive an invitation to join the platform and explore your conversation and others after this conversation is uploaded. Thank you so much for joining us and sharing your thoughts.
